Hi Cary and Milt,

 

This is good timing as I wanted to warn Chicago shinsa attendees about
submitting koshirae. If you submit a tsuka, then the same will apply as with
the NBTHK. Make sure that the tsuka has not been re-wrapped in the last 100
or so years - that means it is no longer antique and will be bounced. Entire
koshirae will be judged based on authenticity and age of all the pieces,
i.e. nothing replaced, re-wrapped or re-lacquered. Also, if pieces are
mumei, they will not be attributed. You must submit the pieces separately
for that. If all or some of the pieces are signed, then they will be
authenticated. 

 

Gordon

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Cary Condell [mailto:condell@...] 
Sent: Monday, January 19, 2004 12:16 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question

 

Milt,
I cannot speak for the NTHK.
Jim will be able to answer the shinsa criteria for fittings.

My experience with the NBTHK is:
You can submit the entire tsuka.
If any element is false (gimei FK, cast menuki)it will not pass.
If all is proper it will paper as "Tsuka mae".
The mei of the FK will be noted.
If there is no mei it will likely be attributed.

The tsuba will require a separate submission.

Twofer's include Daisho Tsuba, Daisho FKs, or Menuki,
Futokoro or Mitokoromono, and of course Daisho koshirae.

Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

http://www.ikkyudo.com
